data.title: Music and Sound not working (Robovm)
data.body:
So I've got my project ported to robovm and the only thing not working now is the music. Music works fine in my desktop and android projects but refuses to work on ios. I get not errors at all about loading so I'm assuming that it's loading properly, it just won't play :/. 

I have tried .mp3, .m4a, and .wav but still no results. 

Just so you know, I have cleared the cache, updated libgdx to the latest nightly build, and cleaned the project. I'm not sure what else to do or if it's a known issue. Is there something special I have to do to make sound work on robovm?

data.title: MipMap, filtering, texture format support for 3D model loaders
data.body: Adding ModelLoader.ModelParameters to support TextureParameter, including MipMapping, Filtering and TextureFormat. Preserves default behavior.

data.title: Added Application#getBatteryPercentage - a cross-platform method to get the battery level
data.body:
- Implemented on Android + iOS
- Returns 100 on Desktop, GWT, and Headless backends because of the native code requirements which may not be available on all platforms
- Minor formatting

This adds an ability for a developer to retrieve the remaining battery level. It is designed to be called periodically, but not every frame. Probably every 10-15 minutes, longer or shorter depending on the power level. This is useful because developers can detect if a device is running low on power and alter game settings for optimal battery performance, show warnings and do other things such as save the game once it runs really low, increase save frequency, disable CPU intensive operations or limit them and more.

data.title: Class com.badlogic.gdx.Gdx doesn't have field gl (Robovm)
data.body:
I'm trying to compile my robovm project using the latex nightlies for robovm and libgdx and I came across this error: 

An internal error occurred during: "Launching DrunkDriver-robovm (2)".
Class com.badlogic.gdx.Gdx doesn't have field gl : com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.GL20; failed to resolve in superclasses and interfaces

When I'm using the stable versions of both, the IOS app crashes after a while. 

Anyways what I tried to do to fix this problem was comment out or remove anything that had to do with GL20 such as GL20.GL_COLOR_BUFFER_BIT)
but that hasn't changed a thing, I keep getting the same error. I'm not sure what to do because there's not much documentation on the IOS platform for libgdx.

data.title: Suggestion: Propose to add Vector3.mad() function
Fixed an issue with fonts that use id values larger than 9999
data.body:
Changed char id number formatting to 6 numbers instead of 5, which was causing issues with japanese fonts with ids larger than 9999.

For example:

```
char id=32   x=2
char id=1235 x=2 
char id=12358x=2
```

The last id is read as "12358x" and not "12358"

On android I get these errors

```
Couldn't load asset '/data/data/com.test.game/files/generated-fonts/roboto32/roboto32.png'

```

Reading them directly using local FileHandle works fine but I'd like to use AssetManager to load them.

I wrote a LocalFileHandleResolver to replace the default InternalFileHandleResolver to handle loading from local storage and set it as the resolver for BitmapFontLoader. 

``` java
assetManager.setLoader(BitmapFont.class, new BitmapFontLoader(new LocalFileHandleResolver()));
```

``` java
public class LocalFileHandleResolver implements FileHandleResolver {
    @Override
    public FileHandle resolve(String fileName) {
        return Gdx.files.local(fileName);
    }
}
```

data.title: Viewports for more comfortable handling of different aspect ratios
data.body:
The previous pull request was this one: https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/pull/1423

I have now tried to put a few more features into the Viewport. It is not as "deeply" integrated into the API as NateS described it, but it can handle a lot more cases now.
- It supports different scaling approaches, namely:
- 1. StretchingViewport: Has a fixed size which gets stretched to fit the screen. Does not keep the aspect ratio
- 2. FixedViewport: Has a fixed size which gets scaled appropriately while keeping the same aspect ratio. This may lead to bars at the border of the screen.
- 3. ScreenViewport: A viewport without a fixed size which gets always scaled up to the screen size.
- 4. Extendable: DoubleRatioViewport or MinMaxViewport which would scale between two viewports are possible, but I didn't have the time to implement those.
- The viewport can be "disabled" which allows to render stuff in the area of the black borders which might appear. I added a quick test for that as well.
- The utility methods for getPickRay, project and unproject now work with both Vector3 and Vector2
- I added some tests to demonstrate the different behaviours in different situations (Stage, Stage with Table, SpriteBatch with OrthographicCamera, Stage with Camera, ModelBatch with PerspectiveCamera), as well to show how the viewport can be used.

So far the viewports are completely additionally, which means they do not break the API anyhow. The viewports might be used, but it's not necessary. The genereal idea behind the viewports was to use them as some kind of "managers" where cameras and stages can be registered and automatically updated as soon as the viewport parameters change.
My next step would have been to integrate the viewport into stage and camera, but I didn't want to touch anything yet.

What do you guys think about it now? Especially Nathan to whom I have talked about the topic the most...
